content.title: Femoral Artery Aneurysm
content.definition: Focal dilation of the common femoral artery (CFA) to ≥1.5 times normal diameter (typically >2.5cm), representing the second most common peripheral aneurysm after popliteal. Often bilateral and associated with other aneurysms (AAA, popliteal).

key_concepts.description: Rare (<1% of arterial aneurysms); strong male predominance (30:1); mean age 65-70; bilateral in 50-70% of cases; 85% have other aneurysms (AAA, popliteal)
Atherosclerosis (most common); anastomotic (post-bypass, post-graft); mycotic (infected); traumatic (iatrogenic - catheterization); connective tissue disorders
True femoral aneurysm: all wall layers involved, usually atherosclerotic, older patients. Pseudoaneurysm: post-catheterization, contained rupture, no true wall, often managed with thrombin injection
Often asymptomatic pulsatile groin mass; may present with local symptoms (pain, compression of femoral vein/nerve); acute limb ischemia from thrombosis/embolization; rupture (rare)
All patients with femoral aneurysm should undergo: abdominal imaging for AAA (50%+ association); bilateral popliteal ultrasound; contralateral femoral evaluation
Thrombosis/embolization (most common complication); limb ischemia; venous compression causing leg swelling/DVT; nerve compression; rupture (<3% but life-threatening)
Symptomatic aneurysms; size >2.5-3cm; rapid growth; thrombus with embolization; compression of adjacent structures
Interposition graft (Dacron or PTFE) with exclusion of aneurysm; maintain profunda femoris patency essential; may need endarterectomy of diseased common femoral
Limited by CFA location (flexion point, profunda origin); covered stent in select cases; typically open repair preferred for true aneurysms
Develops at anastomosis of prior bypass graft (incidence 2-5%); suture line fatigue, infection, progression of disease; requires re-operation with graft extension

content.statement: Femoral Artery Aneurysm is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Femoral-Aneurysm that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Femoral Artery Aneurysm helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Femoral Artery Aneurysm include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Femoral Artery Aneurysm.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

learning_objectives: Define femoral artery aneurysm and distinguish from pseudoaneurysm
Recognize high association with other aneurysms (AAA, popliteal)
Understand indications for repair and surgical approach
Know to preserve profunda femoris during repair
clinical_pearls: Femoral aneurysm → screen for AAA and popliteal aneurysms (50%+ association)
50-70% are bilateral - always check contralateral side
Preserve profunda femoris patency during repair (limb viability)
Anastomotic aneurysm develops years after prior bypass
Open repair preferred over endovascular (flexion point, profunda)
common_mistakes: Missing associated aneurysms (AAA, popliteal) - always screen
Confusing post-catheterization pseudoaneurysm with true aneurysm

sources.source: UpToDate. (2024). Femoral Artery Aneurysm. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
